intro: Ancistrolobus, commonly known as the African mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees in sub-Saharan Africa. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves and white or yellowish flowers. The plant produces small, fleshy berries that are a food source for birds and other animals. Its life cycle involves seeds being dispersed by birds that eat the berries, allowing the plant to spread to new hosts. Ancistrolobus plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its environment, though it can cause stress to its host trees.
